Because Izhmash makes fucking cool shit, and is THE AK factory that has been making them since the original Kalashnikov design. They're also the factory that makes rifles for the Russian military, as well as Molot I believe but those are technically heavy receiver RPKs even the ones they sell as sporting rifles.

The only factory that makes AKs nearly as clean as Izhmash is Arsenal of Bulgaria, but unfortunately they don't use actual AK100 specs because Izhmash sued them over it so they had to change up small things with their SLRs. They also use cheap paint that chips and melts off, and charge ridiculous amounts for their rifles. For reference, Saigas were coming in at $300 while Arsenal USA was changing $1,300 for theirs... It never made sense to buy one when you could invest $1k into mags, ammo, and a whole ass sidearm. Basically though Russian AKs were always the best because they were the most modern design, they had good machining processes, and they knew what worked and what didn't. You won't have the rifle beating itself to death or small parts like a retaining pin falling off, because they've had so much trial and error that they've fixed everything. Meanwhile an American company just starting out doesn't know all those small things that will end up going wrong several thousands of rounds in.

This matters a lot in terms of massing combat power and moving in the rear. It matters less in actual combat where accelerating from a stop to make a bounding off-road dash to new overwatch positions is more important and you're not likely to be anywhere near the theoretical top speed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56346958
Probably not. There aren't any decisive advantages of a mechanized leg system over wheels or tracks for most purposes. They're not fast, they don't offer a maneuver advantage, they're inherently more difficult to stabilize and more maint heavy on account of being mechanically complex. There's also a hell of a lot more surface area vs volume with legged machines so pound for pound they'll never be as well protected or carry comparable armament to a similarly sized conventional vehicle. There's also the question of what happens if one gets stuck or falls over, since you can't exactly just stick a tow line on a mech and haul it out of a ditch.

The only thing that could potentially make them worth it would be the development of a functional MNI that would allow a pilot to control the machine as fluidly as their own body, but even then we're still talking machines that are still comparatively small and specialized. And at that point why not just go with a full power armor system?

Probably the closest you will see to mechs will be squad-level autonomous load-carrying drones, like that big dog thing. Maybe someone will put a 20mm on it for shiggles or something.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56348513
You are overestimating how fast a practical mech would be and downplaying how important the logistical impact the former has.
If the terrain is not bad enough to give legs a maneuverability advantage over tracks, Then a conventional pattern tank will out compete the mech.
Bad terrain can be naturally occurring or manmade but it has to be rough enough to make considering modes of locomotion like legs a viable decision over wheels and tracks.

Making black powder for your own personal use is legal as long as you don't exceed 50 pounds: https://www.atf.gov/explosives/qa/black-powder-subject-regulation-under-federal-explosives-laws

>Black powder is an explosive material for purposes of federal explosives laws and regulations.
>However, the law exempts from regulation commercially manufactured black powder in quantities not exceeding 50 pounds (as well as percussion caps, safety and pyrotechnic fuses, quills, quick and slow matches, and friction primers) intended to be used solely for sporting, recreational, or cultural purposes in antique firearms as defined in 18 U.S.C. 921(a)(16) or in antique devices exempted from the term "destructive device" in 18 U.S.C. 921(a)(4).
>Regardless, persons engaged in the business of importing, manufacturing, or dealing in black powder in any quantity must have a federal explosives license, and comply with recordkeeping, storage and conduct of business requirements.
>[18 U.S.C. 841(c), 841(d), 845(a)(5); 27 CFR 555.11: definitions of "explosives" and "explosive materials", 555.141(b)]

>>56345081
>if you used similar sized steel balls
It doesn't work like that.
Tungsten HMA alloy has density of about 18.5g/cm3. 3mm tungsten ball weights about 0.26 grams and has sectional density of 3.7 grams per cm2.
Steel 3mm ball weights 0.11 grams and has sectional density of 1.57 grams per cm2, 2.4 times less. Steel ball of the same SIZE would have 2.4 times less penetration and lose velocity 2.4 times faster.
To match 3mm tungsten ball sectional density steel ball needs to be 7mm diameter. Such ball would weight 1.4 grams, 5.4 times more. So instead of 180000 tungsten balls you would be able to fit only 33000 steel balls of same penetration capability.

last_replies.com:
>>56345359
I think the issue was implied to be that the first one didn't flex back to straight after a bit of bending.
As for flexing in general there's a few different factors at play. A thinner sword blade can flex further without stressing the material much, but it'll also take less force to bend to far and it'll be floppy in general. A thicker blade will be stiffer (so in a test like that it simply won't bend as far if an equal force is applied), which is a good thing, and take much more force to break but in return it can't bend as far before it's over-stressed. In this respect the thicker blade is basically better, it's just that thickness means weight and we don't want all too much of that.
If we take two pieces of identical shape and look at the material on the other hand we want something that can deform a good amount before it can't spring back to its original shape any more. This also means it can take a lot of force before that happens, since the relationship between force applied and deformation up to that point is largely linear and basically the same for all steels regardless of alloying and tempering. Then once it does start deforming permanently it's nice to have a bit of a safety margin before it snaps completely.
Combining the two we find that in the thicker blade a certain degree of bend demands a greater deformation of the steel at the inside and outside of the curve, making it resist bending more. So it'll break at less bend, but it takes an insane amount of force for that. A very thin blade instead can be rolled up without damage, but is too floppy for use and any force it can't bend out f the way of will ruin it. As for the test shown the difference in thickness could be used to imply a material quality difference that isn't actually there, if (big if) it was done fairly.

>>56345560
The easier it (temporarily) bends the further you must bend it to break it.
The harder it is to bend the more force you need to break it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56346113
As a general rule, the lower the caliber/weaker the weapon, the more situational its effectiveness becomes
for example, a knife can be a good self-defense weapon, if you had proper training, willpower, and the ability to get within range of your target without being overwhelmed/outdone and he was unarmored
a crossbow would make a good self-defense weapon, if you had proper aim, your target was unarmored, and you could prepare a draw fast enough before your target outodes you and closes the gap
A .22LR is a good self-defense weapon, if you can aim effectively and your target is unarmored
A .38 is a good self-defense weapon, if your target is unarmored
a 9mm is a good self-defense weapon generally speaking unless your targets armor is rated beyond 9mm

And so on and so fourth. Literally anything can be lethal given enough time/energy, but the basic concept behind ideal weaponry is how you reduce your variables.

com:

Slow general edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

OK. I was going to suggest these boys get these, and these boys get those, but it's PVS-7s across the board for everyone. They're dated but they generally get the job done. Hot fuck, though - no lasers. Do you at least get tracers? Shooters with the PAS-13s will need to flip the -7s up to switch from I2 observation and movement to targeting. This really slows you down. With PVS-14s you can just shoulder to shoot and resume scooting. Make sure the boys get as much ammo down range as they can to ensure they have a decent idea for how much they need to rely on body index, since they have no lasers. You might want to try having the -7s cammed part way up so you can peek under them to do white light transitions without having to flip them up. Keep in mind that if you need to scoot through a mixed light area under -7s, that you will fail to identify how well you are concealed. Keeping the -7 cammed up will help with this too. If there is any real chance that you will need to unass, then make sure that any magnifiers for observers are using the QD collars. Otherwise one needs to unthread the magnifier to scoot. The magnifiers are pretty great for observation, though.

Saw that stuff in the local shop, how good/bad is it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In no particular order because the optimal lube really depends on the particular firearm and the conditions it will be stored and used in:

The old formula CLP that still had Teflon in it was great for most post-WWII semiautos with tight tolerances. The new formula kinda sucks and tends to just pool up instead of staying where you applied it tbqhfambruh. Biggest downside of both CLP formulas is that they have a pretty strong unpleasant gasoline-y odor that rubs off instantly on anything that they get onto even in very small amounts. CLP's smell and the stains it leaves are really hard to get out of fabrics also so it can easily ruin your clothes if you're not being careful.

The Hoppes oil in
>>56340755
is great for precision bolt guns and milsurp from WWII and earlier. One big advantage is that it doesn't really smell like anything unless you're sniffing it right under your nose.

This picrel Lucas gun oil is a better version of the 3-in-1 and motor oil all the poorfags on here swear by. It's a little more expensive by volume than general purpose oils or CLP but you'll use al lot less of it because it doesn't run and stays slippery over time. It doesn't have anywhere near as strong of an odor as generic oil or CLP and it has some extra additives that make it work better than general purpose oils for firearms specifically.

sub: How do I get into reloading my own ammo?
com: I'm new to deer hunting and so far the only gun I have is a .223 bolt action. Factory ammo is fine for white tail, but I'd also like to kill the odd squirrel and rabbit with it. I'm afraid full power loads are going to shred these critters though so I've been wanting to download a few rounds. The money saving aspect for full power loads is also very appealing to me. What do I need? How do I get started?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56342405
This, there's never any reason to get rid of the single station, they have their uses. I have two on my bench, one is a dedicated decapping station, the other happens to fit some of my very long antique cartridges which there's not enough stroke length for in most presses.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56340463
>Reloading is a big learning curve
Not really. If you're fucking around outside of published recipes or doing something otherwise weird and out of the way like .43 Egyptian then you absolutely need to have a good grounding but the kind of reloading that ninety nine people out of a hundred exclusively do requires little more than attention to detail (especially with modern data and in a modern rifle) and a respect for the fact that if you fuck up you could lose a gun and/or your eye.

>>56340496
>realistically, is it even possible to download .223 to the power of a .22lr?
Depends on the .22 in question. Something like a CCI stinger, sure. Something like subsonic match ammo, probably not. Bullet selection for terminal effect also can be a bit tricky if you want your bullet to do anything besides just pencil.

>won't it be difficult for the primer to set off the round with so much air in the powder space?
With most powders, yes. With Trail Boss, no. More importantly, using that little of a standard powder without some sort of packing is quite dangerous because dude pressure spikes lmao.

>and will it even push the bullet out of a 20" barrel?
Sure, no problem.

>>56340730
Trail Boss is fucking rad. I used it to work up some reduced loads when I was first getting used to my new rifle and it helped my marksmanship a lot.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56342717
Addendum: it is certainly POSSIBLE to drop the velocity of pretty much anything as low as you want but that falls well outside the recipes for even the softest handloads out there and is very much not recommended. If bringing your .223 down to <1500 FPS with Trail Boss isn't enough for you then I would say just bite the bullet and get either a .22 or a .22 mag. Or if you have a grand burning a hole in your pocket and don't mind paying $2/rd. then you could go for a rifle in .22 Hornet, which straddles the line between .22 mag and something like .223.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56327517
I started with a basic RCBS reloading kit, and supplemented it with a digital scale. Dies were extra. I didn't use the powder measure at first. Instead I manually dipped the powder. Once I had a few hundred rounds loaded, and tested, I decided that I needed more kit to keep going and speed up the process. I spent about 2K total on equipment, but I've gotten my money's worth out of it.

You don't NEED a reloading manual if you watch tutorials on youtube and get your load data from the powder maker's website. However, I highly recommend getting at least 2 or 3 manuals, and compare the load data between them when working up a load. Some manuals are more conservative, others have hotter loads.

last_replies.com:

based on my research they make the frames and electronics in the US. the only thing they import are the actual lens, which they do a little polishing on.

>V1: bulk size, considered the best for allround marksmanship, best paired with the magnifier, no irons.
>V2: best as a stand alone red dot for a PCC or shotgun.
>V3: not as many options or utility as the V1, best used on shotguns, pair with magnifier, and/or use cowitness.

these optics are for the casual shooter who need some durability, mostly for bench and light shooting. the thing that kills them compaired to the high end optics is that they are just out of spec, so if eotech is sigma 8, tacticon is sigma 4, sigma 2 is you actualy chinese optics, and sigma 0 is an airsoft optic.

if you want to be pratical it will work, if you want to be tactical, it is best to be prepaired to use a back up if the optic fails from user or maintenance error.

what it is:
>acurate
>true
>not flimsy

what it isn't:
>top spec
>idiot proof/full intative design

there are a handful of situations that the optic can fail, or become irritating.

V1: has a "Wheel" based switch, this mean that can be turned on by brushing against something

V2: is a classic red-dot, but uses LR44 which are not stock available in a Walmart/grocer in the US.

V3: no way to mount flip-up covers, optic mounted magnifiers, or glare-shades.

https://www.cbp.gov/trade/rulings/informed-compliance-publications/marking-country-origin-us-imports
https://www.ftc.gov/business-guidance/resources/complying-made-usa-standard

two articles talk about standards for "made in" markings for import, assembly, and manufacture.

basic rule is that if the product meet the assembled in or made in requirements for a "made in USA" product, then no extraneous markings are required. however if you remove the battery cap on the V1 and V3 it will say "made in USA" on the electronics. the American flag is also considered an "implied" marking for made in the USA/assembled in the USA. the iron sites do not posses markings. the material in the packaging also implies made in the USA.

so if they aren't following import requirements, then they can get in trouble for deceptive advertising. so I say again, the only thing I think they are importing are the lens. which is based on a now deleted video of their behind the scenes. (Also to keep this thread on point, what weapons does Ukraine need now?)

1. For cyber-attacks against Russian elite wealth to dramatically increase. They don't care about the lives of their troops, only their own money.

2. To accelerate the long-range drone program's efforts. By the same token, accelerate the reconstitution of weapons production inside Ukraine itself. Carry out a crash program, akin to how fast China can built a makeshift hospital. Nothing fancy. Just the absolute minimum needed to make weapons.

3. To foment domestic unrest inside Russia itself against the regime. The target is ethnic minorities, disproportionately used as cannon fodder.

4. To continue to amass supplies to protect from the elements: generators, water purifiers, etc. By the same time, continue to amass supplies to repair infrastructure.

5. For a new Winter Offensive and two, keeping all pressure on the invader. As always, wipe out the officers first and rob them of any direction. By the same token, cripple their logistics & communications.

6. The establishment of a Ukrainian Foreign Technical Legion to accelerate repairs to the civilian infrastructure.

7. The systematic targeting of the Russian missile manufacturing capacity within Russia itself. Recovered Russian missile components were dated as recent as a mere months ago, which means they're low on such armaments to be cycled down to such a recent date of manufacture.
